awd_abstract_narration:
This project considers the behavior of solutions of different types of wave equations, including the ultra-hyperbolic Schrodinger equation, the Schrodinger map problem, the Hartree equation, the Skyrme model, and the Einstein wave map system.   These equations are widely separated in their physical and historical origins, however, the relevant mathematics is closely related, and techniques and insights in various areas of mathematics may be synthesized in fruitful ways.  Solutions to these equations exist at least for a short time, but beyond that, can either reach a singularity at some finite time, or extend to all time in which case they are called global solutions.  For singular solutions, the central questions are to find the mechanisms for the breakdown of the solutions and the structure of the solutions as time evolves toward the singularity.  For global solutions, the goal is to catalogue the different possible behaviors of the solution as time extends to infinity, which can include dispersion, the production of cohesive static waveforms or concentrating waveforms. 

The mathematical analysis of these equations applies techniques from geometry, Fourier analysis, and spectral theory.  For some of the equations, the local in time theory is very well understood and is set in a scale-invariant function space that plays a crucial role in the long time analysis of solutions as well.  Despite numerous advances in the last several decades, in many cases it remains an open problem whether a certain initial condition will produce a solution that is singular or global.  It is expected that the solution will behave like a perturbation of a linearized version of the equation in many cases, although there are other known phenomena which occur.  Some of the analytical techniques common to these problems, or which one hopes to apply to these problems, include Morawetz estimates and energy estimates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we study the long time behavior of nonlinear dispersive partial differential equations. Dispersive partial differential equations are known to model many diverse phenomena, from cosmic waves to the dynamics of atomic particles. Despite the vast differences of the phenomena, the relevant mathematics ties the different equations together. In this project, we study the long time behavior of such equations.

Dispersive partial equations are so named because the effect of the linear equation is for the solution to spread out at infinity. However, unlike the heat equation, the solution retains the same ``mass" and ``energy". Additionally, while the behavior of a linear solution is to spread out at infinity, the behavior of a nonlinear solution may be quite different. The nonlinearity may have the effect of attracting the solution, potentially causing blowup to occur.

In this project, we proved that for the defocusing, cubic nonlinear wave equation in three dimensions, global well-posedness and scattering hold for sharp, radially symmetric initial data. Sharp means that a local solution need not exist for data in a larger space. Scattering means that the solution eventually looks like a solution to the linear equation for long time.

For the defocusing, nonlinear Schrodinger equation, we prove a similar result for initial data lying in a Besov space. The Besov space is smaller than the critical Sobolev space, however, the Besov space is also invariant under the scaling. The approach of studying the equation in a Besov space first proved to be an extremely productive approach to the nonlinear wave equation problem.

For the focusing nonlinear Schrodinger equation, scattering is known to fail because solitons exist. However, it is known that for data smaller than a soliton, scattering can hold. We proved that if the data is exactly at the size of the ground state soliton, the only way that scattering can fail is if the solution is a soliton or a pseudoconformal transformation of a soliton.
